page.title: 04Government Morton Hall
page.content: Morton Hall is a large Victorian country house, situated in extensive grounds.It was a private house until the 2nd World War when the whole site was taken over by the RAF, who built huts which are now used as prison accomodation. During the 1950's the Prison Commission acquired the site and opened Morton Hall Borstal. This flourised until the mid 70's when pressure on accomodation eased, allowing the establishment to be moth-balled. For a brief period the officers quarters and kitchen were used to accommodate the Vietnamese refugees. For most of the time Morton Hall has been held on a care and maintenance basis by a small works crew. It was opened again in May 1985 as a prison for 150 category 'D' prisoners to ease overcrowding in Lincoln and other prisons.
